overview.description: A sprawling architectural marvel spread over 2 hectares, the temple is a quintessential example of Dravidian architecture with significant Vijayanagara influences characterized by monumental towers and intricate carvings.

prakaram.name: The Fortress Wall
prakaram.uniqueness: The outer face functions as an open-air museum
prakaram.description: The massive compound wall is unique in South Indian architecture for its sculptural density—3,200 stones carved with religious and social scenes, offering a visual archive of 15th century life.

gopurams.name: Eastern Gopuram (Maha Dwaram)
gopurams.description: The main entrance and tallest tower, lavishly ornamented in Vijayanagara style

gopurams.name: Northern Gopuram (Shivaji Gopuram)
gopurams.description: Constructed by the Maratha king during his southern campaign
gopurams.notable: Features Maratha-influenced finials and architectural elements

gopurams.name: Southern Gopuram
gopurams.description: One of the earlier Vijayanagara additions

linga.form: Relatively small and flat, protruding only a few inches above the peetham
linga.significance: The archaic, low form suggests its ancient natural origins—likely worshipped as a rock formation before temple construction

mandapas.name: Mukha Mandapa
mandapas.features: Pillars with intricate carvings of lions and yalis

mandapas.name: Nandi Mandapa
mandapas.description: Large pavilion housing the sacred bull

nandi.style: Masterpiece of realism with veins and ornaments in high relief

mandapas.name: Viroopaksha Mandapa (Veerasiro Mandapa)
mandapas.historical_significance: Site of the Virashaiva 'Sarvarpana' sacrifices where devotees historically offered their limbs or heads to the deity

mandapas.name: Salu Mandapas
mandapas.description: Pillared corridors lining the car streets

bhramaramba_shrine.location: West of Mallikarjuna sanctum, within same enclosure

sri_chakra.purpose: To pacify the fierce (Ugra) energy of the Goddess, making her benevolent for worship

subsidiary_shrines.name: Vriddha Mallikarjuna
subsidiary_shrines.significance: Houses an older Linga, possibly the original deity before temple expansion

subsidiary_shrines.name: Sahasra Linga
subsidiary_shrines.description: A Linga carved with 1,000 miniature Lingas on its surface
subsidiary_shrines.legend: Commissioned by Lord Rama to atone for killing Ravana (a Brahmin)

subsidiary_shrines.name: Pandava Lingas
subsidiary_shrines.description: Five Shiva Lingas believed installed by the five Pandava brothers during their forest exile

subsidiary_shrines.name: Sakshi Ganapati
subsidiary_shrines.significance: The Witness Ganapati—traditionally visited first to remove obstacles before darshan

subsidiary_shrines.name: Mirror Hall
subsidiary_shrines.description: Features mirrors creating infinite reflections of a Nataraja idol
